content.title: Inflation, Unemployment, and Personal Finance
content.subtitle: Understand how rising prices and job loss affect your purchasing power and financial resilience in {{STATE_NAME}}

content.label: Essential Question
content.question:
If prices rise 6% but your salary only rises 3%, did you actually get a raise?

Inflation silently erodes your purchasing power ‚Äî and understanding it is essential for protecting your financial future in {{STATE_NAME}}.

objectives.description: The three types of unemployment ‚Äî frictional, structural, and cyclical ‚Äî and explain the economic causes and personal implications of each
Real versus nominal values using the Consumer Price Index (CPI) to determine actual purchasing power changes over time
How inflation erodes purchasing power, affects savings, and creates winners and losers in the economy
Strategies to protect personal finances from inflation and unemployment risk in {{STATE_NAME}}

terms.definition: A sustained increase in the general price level of goods and services over time, reducing the purchasing power of money ‚Äî measured by the Consumer Price Index (CPI)
terms.example: A grocery cart that cost $100 in 2020 cost approximately $130 by 2023 ‚Äî 30% inflation over three years reduced the real value of every dollar held in cash

terms.definition: A measure of the average change in prices paid by consumers for a basket of goods and services ‚Äî the primary tool for calculating inflation rates and adjusting wages for real purchasing power
terms.example: The BLS tracks prices for food, housing, transportation, healthcare, and clothing ‚Äî if the CPI rises 4%, average prices increased 4% and your dollar buys 4% less

terms.definition: Unemployment caused by a mismatch between workers' skills and the skills demanded by employers ‚Äî often resulting from technological change or industry shifts that make certain jobs obsolete
terms.example: A coal miner whose job is eliminated by automation, or a travel agent replaced by booking websites ‚Äî their skills no longer match available jobs in the economy

terms.definition: The real quantity of goods and services that a unit of money can buy ‚Äî inflation reduces purchasing power over time while deflation increases it
terms.example: A $50,000 salary in 2020 had the same purchasing power as roughly $62,000 in 2024 after 24% cumulative inflation ‚Äî a real wage cut if salary stayed at $50,000

leftColumn.title: Temporary & Structural
items: Frictional ‚Äî Temporary unemployment between jobs; normal part of a healthy labor market
Example: Graduate searching for first job after college in {{STATE_NAME}}
Structural ‚Äî Skills mismatch due to technology, industry shifts, or offshoring
Example: Factory worker displaced by automation needing retraining
Both are harder to solve with just monetary or fiscal policy

rightColumn.title: Cyclical (Economic)
items: Cyclical ‚Äî Caused by economic downturns; workers laid off due to falling demand
Example: Restaurant workers laid off during COVID-19 recession in {{STATE_NAME}}
Rises sharply during recessions; falls quickly during recoveries
Primary target of fiscal stimulus and Fed rate cuts
Measured by the unemployment rate ‚Äî current {{STATE_NAME}} rate reflects this

leftPanel.title: Who Inflation Helps and Hurts
paragraphs: Inflation isn't equally bad for everyone ‚Äî it creates winners and losers depending on your financial position. Understanding which side you're on helps you make better decisions.
bulletPoints: HURT: Savers holding cash ‚Äî buying power erodes as prices rise (a $10,000 savings at 0% during 6% inflation loses $600 in real value each year)
HURT: Fixed-income recipients ‚Äî retirees on fixed pensions see their real income shrink each year
HELPED: Borrowers with fixed-rate loans ‚Äî debt repaid in cheaper future dollars (mortgage payment stays at $1,200 while $1,200 buys less over time)
HELPED: Owners of real assets ‚Äî real estate and commodity prices typically rise with inflation, preserving wealth

stats.label: Real value lost annually on $10,000 cash savings during 6% inflation with 0% savings rate
Cumulative price increase 2020-2023 ‚Äî meaning 2020 dollars bought 30% more
Treasury Inflation-Protected Securities ‚Äî bonds that adjust principal for inflation

layoutData.title: The Difference Between Nominal and Real
paragraphs: Nominal values are measured in current dollars ‚Äî they don't account for inflation. Real values adjust for inflation to show actual purchasing power. This distinction is critical for understanding whether you're getting ahead or falling behind.
bulletPoints: Nominal Wage: Your $45,000 salary in 2024 ‚Äî the number on your paycheck before adjusting for price changes
Real Wage: Your $45,000 salary divided by the price index ‚Äî reveals whether your actual purchasing power increased or decreased
Calculation: Real Value = Nominal Value √∑ (CPI / 100). If CPI rose from 100 to 108, real wages fell by 8% for those whose nominal wages didn't increase
Real Interest Rate: Nominal rate minus inflation. A 2% savings account during 4% inflation = -2% real return ‚Äî you're losing purchasing power every year

keyPoint.text: üí° From 2021-2023, nominal wages rose ~4% per year ‚Äî but inflation averaged 6-7%. Real wages fell for most workers. Your paycheck went up but bought less. Always think in real terms, not nominal.

leftPanel.title: Financial and Emotional Impact of Job Loss
paragraphs: Unemployment isn't just a statistic ‚Äî it's a financial emergency. Understanding the true cost helps you prepare emergency savings and know your options in {{STATE_NAME}}.
bulletPoints: Lost Income ‚Äî Average unemployment lasts 4-6 months; UI benefits replace only 40-50% of wages
Benefit Gap ‚Äî UI in {{STATE_NAME}} typically maxes at $300-$600/week ‚Äî far below most workers' full salaries
Healthcare Risk ‚Äî Job loss means losing employer health insurance; COBRA coverage is expensive
Skill Erosion ‚Äî Extended unemployment makes returning to work harder as skills and networks atrophy
Emergency Fund Necessity ‚Äî 3-6 months of expenses prevents financial catastrophe during job loss in {{STATE_NAME}}

stats.label: Wage replacement rate from unemployment insurance ‚Äî not enough to maintain most lifestyles

Emergency fund target ‚Äî months of expenses to survive job loss in {{STATE_NAME}}

leftPanel.title: What Drives Prices Up?
paragraphs: Inflation has multiple causes ‚Äî understanding them helps you anticipate which sectors will be hit hardest and how long price increases are likely to last.
bulletPoints: Demand-Pull ‚Äî Too much money chasing too few goods; economy overheating (stimulus check effect in 2021)
Cost-Push ‚Äî Rising production costs passed to consumers (supply chain disruptions, energy price spikes)
Built-in Inflation ‚Äî Wage-price spiral: workers demand higher wages ‚Üí businesses raise prices ‚Üí workers demand higher wages again
Monetary ‚Äî Too much money printed relative to economic output (reduces value of each dollar)
Supply Shocks ‚Äî Sudden disruptions like COVID or geopolitical events spike prices in key sectors affecting {{STATE_NAME}}

stats.label: Primary cause of 2021-2022 US inflation ‚Äî $5T in stimulus met reduced supply
2022 energy and food inflation ‚Äî Russia-Ukraine war disrupted global supply
Fed's target inflation rate ‚Äî moderate inflation considered healthy for economic growth

layoutData.title: Strategies That Beat Inflation
paragraphs: You can't control inflation, but you can protect your financial position from it. Smart strategies ensure your wealth grows in real terms, not just nominally.
bulletPoints: Invest in Stocks: Historically, stock market returns (~7% real) exceed inflation ‚Äî S&P 500 index funds provide the best long-term inflation protection for most investors
Real Estate: Property values and rents typically rise with inflation ‚Äî home ownership in {{STATE_NAME}} can preserve wealth during inflationary periods
I-Bonds and TIPS: Government bonds specifically designed to rise with CPI ‚Äî guaranteed inflation protection for conservative savers
Negotiate Salary: Annual raises below the inflation rate are real pay cuts ‚Äî know the CPI when negotiating compensation in {{STATE_NAME}}

keyPoint.text: üí° $10,000 in a savings account earning 0.5% loses real value during any inflation above 0.5%. The same $10,000 invested in an S&P 500 index fund historically grows ~7% real per year ‚Äî the difference between falling behind and building wealth.

leftPanel.title: Building Your Financial Safety Net
paragraphs: Unemployment can strike anyone regardless of performance ‚Äî company layoffs, industry downturns, and automation affect workers across all education levels. Preparation is essential.
bulletPoints: Emergency Fund ‚Äî 3-6 months of essential expenses in a high-yield savings account; your first line of defense
Marketable Skills ‚Äî Continuously update skills to avoid structural unemployment; take online courses, certifications in growing {{STATE_NAME}} industries
Professional Network ‚Äî Maintain connections; most jobs in {{STATE_NAME}} are found through networking, not job boards
Multiple Income Streams ‚Äî Side income reduces dependence on any single employer; freelancing, part-time work, or investment income
Unemployment Insurance ‚Äî File immediately upon job loss in {{STATE_NAME}}; don't wait ‚Äî benefits help while you job search

stats.label: File for unemployment benefits in {{STATE_NAME}} immediately ‚Äî don't delay
Of jobs filled through networking ‚Äî professional connections are your best job search tool
Monthly income gap between UI benefits and average salary ‚Äî emergency fund covers this difference

scenario.name: Taylor ‚Äî The Silent Wage Cut
paragraphs: Taylor received a 3% raise at her job in {{STATE_NAME}} ‚Äî her first raise in two years. She was excited until she looked at the numbers more carefully. Inflation that year was 6.5%.

Despite the nominal raise, Taylor's real purchasing power fell 3.5% ‚Äî she could afford 3.5% less with her higher paycheck than she could the year before. She used this information to negotiate a larger raise the following year.

scenario.name: Marcus ‚Äî Structural Unemployment and Retraining
paragraphs: Marcus worked in a printing plant in {{STATE_NAME}} for 12 years when the company automated his department. His job was eliminated ‚Äî not due to poor performance, but because machines now do the work faster and cheaper.

Marcus faced structural unemployment. He enrolled in a 9-month coding bootcamp funded by a {{STATE_NAME}} workforce development grant, transitioned to web development, and now earns 40% more than his previous salary ‚Äî turning displacement into advancement.

takeaways.title: Three Types, Three Causes
takeaways.description: Frictional unemployment is temporary and normal; structural requires retraining; cyclical responds to economic policy ‚Äî each needs different solutions

takeaways.title: Real vs. Nominal ‚Äî Always Adjust
takeaways.description: A raise below the inflation rate is a real pay cut ‚Äî always compare nominal values to CPI when evaluating wages, returns, and debt in {{STATE_NAME}}

takeaways.title: Inflation Creates Winners and Losers
takeaways.description: Cash savers and fixed-income recipients lose; asset owners and fixed-rate borrowers win ‚Äî your financial position determines your inflation exposure

takeaways.title: Prepare for Both Risks
takeaways.description: Emergency fund for unemployment, inflation-beating investments for long-term wealth ‚Äî these two strategies address the most common financial threats in {{STATE_NAME}}
